LECTURE: In a soccer match, players often switch positions during the game. This is called positional change.
Why do players change positions?
There are many reasons why a player might be switched to a different position. A coach might decide to change a player's position to take advantage of that player's strengths. For example, a fast runner might be moved to a forward position. Or, a player might be switched to a different position to help her team. For example, a defender might be moved to a midfielder position to help her team keep the ball out of its own net.
How do positional changes affect players?
Changes to a player's position can affect that player's role on the team. For example, a forward is often responsible for scoring goals. So, if a forward is switched to a midfielder position, they may have to adjust their role to include less scoring and more passing.
Positional changes can also affect how a player contributes to the team. For example, a midfielder in a defensive position may be responsible for defending against the other team's forward. But, if they are switched to an offensive position, they may be responsible for helping to score goals.
SOLUTION: At the end of the match, Claire is playing. Bob is not playing. So, Claire is playing cheerleader.

(B) Moby Dick
(C) Lolita
(D) The Fellowship of the Ring

model_answer:
LECTURE: Networks can be used to model trade. In a network, each person is a node, and each book is an edge. Each edge connects two nodes, one from each person.
The price of a book affects which books are traded. Books that are cheaper have more edges connecting to them. So, in this model, prices affect which books are traded, but prices do not affect which books are read.
SOLUTION: The prices of the books are given in the table below. Each price is the base price for the book.

The most important downside of nuclear power is the risk of a meltdown. A meltdown occurs when the fuel rods in a nuclear reactor overheat and start to melt. Meltdowns can release large amounts of radioactive material into the environment.
Another downside of nuclear power is the storage of nuclear waste. Nuclear waste is highly radioactive and can be dangerous for thousands of years.

This analysis should include the environmental and health costs of a potential meltdown, as well as the economic benefits of producing electricity with nuclear power.
